狮子、熊和狐狸: 一头狮子和一头熊同时抓到了一只小山羊。他们都想将其据为己有,便凶猛地厮打了起来。经过长时间的苦斗，狮子和熊都损伤惨重，变得虚弱无力，最后精疲力竭地瘫倒在了地上。一只狐狸，在他们的远处已经来来回回地转悠好几次了。他看见狮子和熊都四肢摊开趴在地上，小山羊就放在他们中间，谁也没有触碰到。于是，狐狸冲到狮子和熊中间，叼起小山羊，以最快的速度逃之夭夭了。狮子和熊眼睁睁地看着狐狸这样做，可谁也无力起身，于是说道：“我们真是可悲啊，我们自相残杀，最后却让狐狸得了便宜。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Lion and a Bear seized a Kid at the same moment, and fought fiercely for its possession.When they had fearfully lacerated each other and were faint from the long combat, they lay down exhausted with fatigue.A Fox, who had gone round them at a distance several times, saw them both stretched on the ground with the Kid lying untouched in the middle.He ran in between them, seized the Kid and scampered off as fast as he could.The Lion and the Bear saw him, but not being able to get up, said, “Woe be to us, that we fought and belabored ourselves only to serve the turn of a Fox.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 鹬蚌相争，渔翁得利，这是常有的事。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: It sometimes happens that one man has all the toil, and another all the profit.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 母鹿和狮子
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Doe and the Lion

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只母鹿为了躲避猎人的穷追不舍，躲进了狮子的洞穴。一看见母鹿跑过来，狮子便将自己隐藏了起来，等母鹿在洞穴里脱离险情之后，狮子便朝母鹿扑去，把它撕了个粉碎。“我真倒霉啊，”母鹿大叫道，“刚从猎人之手逃脱，不料却又将自己送入了野兽之口。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Doe hard pressed by hunters sought refuge in a cave belonging to a Lion.The Lion concealed himself on seeing her approach, but when she was safe within the cave, sprang upon her and tore her to pieces.“Woe is me,” exclaimed the Doe, “who have escaped from man, only to throw myself into the mouth of a wild beast.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 躲避一个灾祸时，一定要当心，不要陷入另一个灾祸。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: In avoiding one evil, care must be taken not to fall into another.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 农夫和狐狸
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Farmer and the Fox

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狐狸偷袭了农夫的家禽饲养场，农夫因此对狐狸怀恨在心，最终逮到了它。农夫决定好好报复它一番，便将浸泡了油的绳子系在狐狸的尾巴上，并点着了火。天意叵测，狐狸竟然冲向了刚抓它的这个农夫的田地里。此时正值小麦收获的时节，但是这一年农夫却颗粒无收，最后悲痛万分地回家了。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Farmer, who bore a grudge against a Fox for robbing his poultry yard, caught him at last, and being determined to take an ample revenge, tied some rope well soaked in oil to his tail, and set it on fire.The Fox by a strange fatality rushed to the fields of the Farmer who had captured him.It was the time of the wheat harvest; but the Farmer reaped nothing that year and returned home grieving sorely.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 海鸥和鸢
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Seagull and the Kite

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只海鸥狼吞虎咽地吃下了一条很大的鱼，结果撑破了自己的肚子，躺在海岸边，奄奄一息。一只鸢看到这只海鸥，说道：“你真是自作孽啊，因为作为一只在空中翱翔的鸟，你就没有权利从海里觅食。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Seagull having bolted down too large a fish, burst its deep gullet-bag and lay down on the shore to die.A Kite saw him and exclaimed: “You richly deserve your fate; for a bird of the air has no business to seek its food from the sea.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 每个人都应该知足常乐、安分守己。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Every man should be content to mind his own business.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 哲学家、蚂蚁和墨丘利
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Philosopher, the Ants, and Mercury

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一位哲学家在岸边目睹了一艘船失事，船上的所有船员和乘客都溺水死了。哲学家痛斥上帝的不公，说上帝只是因为一个罪犯或许在船上，就让这么多无辜的人丧生。当哲学家沉浸在这些思绪之中时，发现自己被一大群蚂蚁包围了；他当时站在蚁穴附近。其中一只蚂蚁爬到了哲学家身上，还叮了他一口，于是他立刻踩死了所有的蚂蚁。此时，众神的信使墨丘利现身了，用他的魔杖敲打了一下哲学家，说：“你真以为你自己可以评判上帝的行为吗？你自己不也是以同样的方式对待这些可怜的蚂蚁吗？”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Philosopher witnessed from the shore the shipwreck of a vessel, of which the crew and passengers were all drowned.He inveighed against the injustice of Providence, which would for the sake of one criminal perchance sailing in the ship allow so many innocent persons to perish.As he was indulging in these reflections, he found himself surrounded by a whole army of Ants, near whose nest he was standing.One of them climbed up and stung him, and he immediately trampled them all to death with his foot.Mercury presented himself, and striking the Philosopher with his wand, said, “And are you indeed to make yourself a judge of the dealings of Providence, who hast thyself in a similar manner treated these poor Ants?”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 老鼠和公牛
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Mouse and the Bull

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一头公牛被老鼠咬了一口。伤口令公牛气愤不已，于是公牛便尽力去逮老鼠。但老鼠却安然无恙地逃回到了自己的洞里。尽管公牛用犄角拱进了墙壁，可还没等拱到老鼠，他就累得趴下了，在洞口外睡着了。这时，老鼠探头出来，鬼鬼祟祟地爬到公牛的胁腹，又咬了他一口，然后撤回到自己的洞里。公牛跳了起来，不知如何是好，又是伤心，又是困惑不解。这时，老鼠说道：“庞然大物未必总能战无不胜。有些时候，弱小者和卑微者最善于招惹是非。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Bull was bitten by a Mouse and, angered by the wound, tried to capture him.But the Mouse reached his hole in safety.Though the Bull dug into the walls with his horns, he tired before he could rout out the Mouse, and crouching down, went to sleep outside the hole.The Mouse peeped out, crept furtively up his flank, and again biting him, retreated to his hole.The Bull rising up, and not knowing what to do, was sadly perplexed. At which the Mouse said, “The great do not always prevail.There are times when the small and lowly are the strongest to do mischief.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狮子和野兔
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Lion and the Hare

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一头狮子无意中发现了一只熟睡的野兔。正当狮子想要去抓野兔时，一只年轻力壮的雄鹿跑了过去。于是，狮子丢下野兔，去追雄鹿了。这只野兔被追逐声惊醒，飞奔而去了。狮子追了很长时间也没能捉到那只雄鹿，于是它折回来想去吃野兔。狮子发现野兔也没影了，说道：“我真是自作自受，为了有机会获得更多，竟把到手的猎物给放跑了。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Lion came across a Hare, who was fast asleep.He was just in the act of seizing her, when a fine young Hart trotted by, and he left the Hare to follow him.The Hare, scared by the noise, awoke and scudded away.The Lion was unable after a long chase to catch the Hart, and returned to feed upon the Hare.On finding that the Hare also had run off, he said, “I am rightly served, for having let go of the food that I had in my hand for the chance of obtaining more.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 农夫和老鹰
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Peasant and the Eagle

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一位农夫发现一只老鹰被困在了陷阱里，出于对老鹰的无比崇敬，农夫救了它。对自己的救命恩人，老鹰并没有忘恩负义。它看到农夫坐在一堵危墙下，便朝农夫飞去，用自己的爪子从农夫头上抓起了一个包袱。等农夫站起身去追时，老鹰又把包袱丢还给了他。农夫捡起包袱，回到刚刚就坐的墙脚，发现那堵墙已经塌了；农夫对老鹰的帮助惊叹不已。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Peasant found an Eagle captured in a trap, and much admiring the bird, set him free.The Eagle did not prove ungrateful to his deliverer, for seeing the Peasant sitting under a wall which was not safe, he flew toward him and with his talons snatched a bundle from his head.When the Peasant rose in pursuit, the Eagle let the bundle fall again.Taking it up, the man returned to the same place, to find that the wall under which he had been sitting had fallen to pieces; and he marveled at the service rendered him by the Eagle.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 墨丘利神木像和木匠
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Image of Mercury and the Carpenter

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一个很穷的木匠有一尊木制的墨丘利神像。他每天都在神像前供奉祭拜，恳求神像让自己变得富有。但是，尽管如此祈求，他却变得越来越穷了。最后，暴怒之下，木匠将神像从其底座上拿下来，然后把它猛摔向墙。结果，神像的头被撞掉了，从里面流出了一股金沙。木匠赶紧捧起金沙，说道：“哎呀，我觉得你完全是自相矛盾、不可理喻嘛；我尊敬你时，一无所获，如今我虐待你，你倒给我一大笔财富。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A very poor man, a Carpenter by trade, had a wooden image of Mercury, before which he made offerings day by day, and begged the idol to make him rich, but in spite of his entreaties he became poorer and poorer.At last, being very angry, he took his image down from its pedestal and dashed it against the wall. When its head was knocked off, out came a stream of gold, which the Carpenter quickly picked up and said, “Well, I think thou art altogether contradictory and unreasonable; for when I paid you honor, I reaped no benefits: but now that I maltreat you I am loaded with an abundance of riches.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 公牛和山羊
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Bull and the Goat

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一头公牛，为了逃脱狮子的魔爪，躲进了一个山洞里。这个山洞最近被一些牧羊人占用了。公牛刚一进山洞，一只留守在洞中的公山羊就用犄角向公牛发起了猛攻。公牛平静地对公山羊说：“尽管用你的角顶我吧。我一点儿也不怕你，我害怕的是狮子。等那怪物走开，我马上就会让你知道一只山羊和一头公牛在力量上孰高孰低。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Bull, escaping from a Lion, hid in a cave which some shepherds had recently occupied.As soon as he entered, a He-Goat left in the cave sharply attacked him with his horns.The Bull quietly addressed him: “Butt away as much as you will.I have no fear of you, but of the Lion.Let that monster go away and I will soon let you know what is the respective strength of a Goat and a Bull.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 友人遭遇不幸时落井下石是品行恶劣的表现。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: It shows an evil disposition to take advantage of a friend in distress.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 跳舞的猴子们
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Dancing Monkeys

狮子、熊和狐狸: 有个王子训练了好几只猴子学跳舞。猴子天生就极会模仿人类的动作，以此显示自己是最聪明的学徒；当给它们穿上华丽的衣服，戴上各色面具时，它们就会手舞足蹈，跳得简直可以和朝中任何一位大臣相媲美。猴子们的表演常赢来阵阵热烈的掌声。直到有一次，一位大臣一心想搞恶作剧，便从他的口袋里掏出一把坚果扔到了舞台上。猴子们一看到坚果就忘记自己在跳舞了，重又恢复了猴子的本性（它们本来就是），不表演了。猴子们扯下面具，撕破长袍，互相为争夺坚果打起架来。于是，舞蹈表演便在观众的笑声和嘲弄声中落幕了。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A prince had some Monkeys trained to dance.Being naturally great mimics of men’s actions, they showed themselves most apt pupils, and when arrayed in their rich clothes and masks, they danced as well as any of the courtiers.The spectacle was often repeated with great applause, till on one occasion a courtier, bent on mischief, took from his pocket a handful of nuts and threw them upon the stage.The Monkeys at the sight of the nuts forgot their dancing and became (as indeed they were) Monkeys instead of actors.Pulling off their masks and tearing their robes, they fought with one another for the nuts.The dancing spectacle thus came to an end amidst the laughter and ridicule of the audience.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狐狸和豹
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Fox and the Leopard

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狐狸和豹为谁更美丽而争论不休。豹一一展示点缀在自己皮肤上那形色各异的斑点。但是狐狸打断了豹，说道：“我比你可是美多了。我的美不在于外表的修饰，而在于头脑的充实。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Fox and the Leopard disputed which was the more beautiful of the two.The Leopard exhibited one by one the various spots which decorated his skin.But the Fox, interrupting him, said, “And how much more beautiful than you am I, who am decorated, not in body, but in mind.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 小猴子和他们的妈妈
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Monkeys and Their Mother

狮子、熊和狐狸: 传说有一只母猴，一胞生下了两只小猴子。猴妈妈爱抚和哺育其中一只，投入了极大的关爱，但却厌恶、忽视另一只小猴子。结果有一次，被妈妈爱抚和宠爱的那只小猴子因过度的母爱窒息而死了；而被嫌弃的那只猴子，尽管受到忽视，却茁壮成长着。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Monkey, it is said, has two young ones at each birth.The Mother fondles one and nurtures it with the greatest affection and care, but hates and neglects the other.It happened once that the young one which was caressed and loved was smothered by the too great affection of the Mother, while the despised one was nurtured and reared in spite of the neglect to which it was exposed.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 最好的意愿并非总能成功。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The best intentions will not always ensure success.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 橡树和朱庇特
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Oaks and Jupiter

狮子、熊和狐狸: 橡树向朱庇特抱怨说：“我们白白地承受着生活的重担，在所有生长的树木中，我们橡树最常处于不断被砍伐的危险之中。”朱庇特回答说：“你们所遭受的不幸只能怪你们自己：因为如果你们没有造出这么上好的柱子和杆子，向木匠和农夫们证明你们是如此耐用，那么斧子就不会那么频繁地被放到你们的根部了。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Oaks presented a complaint to Jupiter, saying, “We bear for no purpose the burden of life, as of all the trees that grow we are the most continually in peril of the axe.”Jupiter made answer: “You have only to thank yourselves for the misfortunes to which you are exposed: for if you did not make such excellent pillars and posts, and prove yourselves so serviceable to the carpenters and the farmers, the axe would not so frequently be laid to your roots.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 野兔和猎狗
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Hare and the Hound

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一条猎狗把一只野兔从兔窝里追赶出来，但追捕了一长段路程之后，猎狗放弃了。一个山羊倌看到猎狗停了下来，就取笑它说：“较小的那个竟跑赢了。” 猎狗回答道：“你没有看到我们之间的区别：我奔跑只是为了一顿晚餐，而野兔则是为了活命。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Hound started a Hare from his lair, but after a long run, gave up the chase.A goat-herd seeing him stop, mocked him, saying “The little one is the best runner of the two.”The Hound replied, “You do not see the difference between us: I was only running for a dinner, but he for his life.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 旅行者和命运女神
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Traveler and Fortune

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一个旅行者经过一段漫长的旅途，感到筋疲力竭，累倒在一口深井的边沿上。就在他快要掉进水里时，传说命运女神出现在了他的面前，把他从昏睡中唤醒，对他说：“好先生，请醒醒吧，因为你若掉进井里，我就会受到人们的谴责，在凡间背上恶名；因为我发现人们总是会把不幸归咎于我，尽管事实上更多的是他们自己的愚蠢导致了他们的不幸。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Traveler wearied from a long journey lay down, overcome with fatigue, on the very brink of a deep well.Just as he was about to fall into the water, Dame Fortune, it is said, appeared to him and waking him from his slumber thus addressed him: “Good Sir, pray wake up: for if you fall into the well, the blame will be thrown on me, and I shall get an ill name among mortals; for I find that men are sure to impute their calamities to me, however much by their own folly they have really brought them on themselves.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 每个人都或多或少掌控着自己的命运。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Everyone is more or less master of his own fate.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 秃头骑士
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Bald Knight

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一个秃头骑士戴着假发出去打猎。突然一阵风吹来，吹掉了他的帽子和假发，引得同伴们一阵大笑。骑士勒住了马，和其他人一起兴高采烈地自嘲道：“这些头发连长出它们的人都抛弃了，如今竟然从我的头上飞走了，真是奇怪！”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A bald knight, who wore a wig, went out to hunt.A sudden puff of wind blew off his hat and wig, at which a loud laugh rang forth from his companions.He pulled up his horse, and with great glee joined in the joke by saying, “What a marvel it is that hairs which are not mine should fly from me, when they have forsaken even the man on whose head they grew.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 牧羊人和狗
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Shepherd and the Dog

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一个牧羊人把他的羊群关入羊栏里过夜，并打算把一只狼也关进去。他的狗觉察到了那只狼，便对主人说：“主人啊，如果你让一只狼进入羊栏中，你怎么还能认为羊是安全的呢？”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Shepherd penning his sheep in the fold for the night was about to shut up a wolf with them, when his Dog perceiving the wolf said, “Master, how can you expect the sheep to be safe if you admit a wolf into the fold?”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 油灯
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Lamp

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一盏油灯因浸入了太多的油而灯火闪亮。它便吹嘘说自己比太阳发出的光还要明亮。突然，一阵风起，油灯立刻被吹灭了。油灯的主人再次将它点亮，说道：“不要再吹嘘了，从今以后，知足些，安安静静地释放你的光芒吧。要知道，就连星星都是不需要被重新点亮的。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Lamp, soaked with too much oil and flaring brightly, boasted that it gave more light than the sun.Then a sudden puff of wind arose, and the Lamp was immediately extinguished.Its owner lit it again, and said: “Boast no more, but henceforth be content to give thy light in silence.Know that not even the stars need to be relit.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狮子、狐狸和驴
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Lion, the Fox, and the Ass

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狮子、狐狸和驴达成协议，在追捕猎物时相互协助。他们捕获了一大堆猎物。在从森林回来的路上，狮子让驴根据约定的各人应得的份额分给他们应得的那份。驴仔细地把猎物分成均等的三份，并谦逊地请另外两位先挑。狮子大怒，一口吞掉了驴。然后，狮子又让狐狸帮助他分。狐狸把他们猎来的食物堆成一个大堆，自己只留了一丁点。狮子说：“我了不起的伙伴啊，是谁教给了你这分割的艺术呢？你可真是太娴熟了。”狐狸回答道：“我是从驴那里学会的，因为我看到了他的下场。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Lion, the Fox and the Ass entered into an agreement to assist each other in the chase.Having secured a large booty, the Lion on their return from the forest asked the Ass to allot his due portion to each of the three partners in the treaty.The Ass carefully divided the spoil into three equal shares and modestly requested the two others to make the first choice.The Lion, bursting out into a great rage, devoured the Ass.Then he requested the Fox to do him the favor to make a division.The Fox accumulated all that they had killed into one large heap and left to himself the smallest possible morsel.The Lion said, “Who has taught you, my very excellent fellow, the art of division?You are perfect to a fraction.”He replied, “I learned it from the Ass, by witnessing his fate.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 能从别人的不幸中汲取经验教训的人是幸运的。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Happy is the man who learns from the misfortunes of others.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 公牛、母狮子和野猪猎手
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Bull, the Lioness, and the Wild-Boar Hunter

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一头公牛发现一头熟睡的幼狮，就用它的牛角把幼狮抵死了。母狮子走过来，看到死去的幼师悲痛不已。远远站着一个野猪猎手，看到这头母狮子如此悲伤，便对它说：“想想有多少人得为他们死去的孩子而悲伤啊，而那些孩子的死则是你一手造成的。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Bull finding a lion’s cub asleep gored him to death with his horns.The Lioness came up, and bitterly lamented the death of her whelp.A wild-boar Hunter, seeing her distress, stood at a distance and said to her, “Think how many men there are who have reason to lament the loss of their children, whose deaths have been caused by you.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 橡树和伐木工们
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Oak and the Woodcutters

狮子、熊和狐狸: 伐木工们砍倒了一棵山上的橡树，然后把树劈成了块状，又用树枝做成楔子，再用楔子去劈开树干。橡树哀叹道：“我不在乎斧子朝我的树根上砍去，但是，我是被用自己的树枝做成的楔子劈开的，这让我觉得很伤心。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Woodcutters cut down a Mountain Oak and split it in pieces, making wedges of its own branches for dividing the trunk.The Oak said with a sigh, “I do not care about the blows of the axe aimed at my roots, but I do grieve at being torn in pieces by these wedges made from my own branches.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 自身带来的不幸是最让人难以承受的。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Misfortunes springing from ourselves are the hardest to bear.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 母鸡和金蛋
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Hen and the Golden Eggs

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一对乡下夫妇有一只母鸡，它每天都下一个金蛋。夫妇俩猜想这只母鸡体内一定存有一大块金子。为了得到这些金子，他们把母鸡给杀了。杀死母鸡后，他们惊讶地发现这只母鸡和他们的其他母鸡在各方面都没有什么不同。这对愚蠢的夫妇希望一夜暴富，却最终丧失了原本每天都能确保获得的收益。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A cottager and his wife had a Hen that laid a golden egg every day.They supposed that the Hen must contain a great lump of gold in its inside, and in order to get the gold they killed it.Having done so, they found to their surprise that the Hen differed in no respect from their other hens.The foolish pair, thus hoping to become rich all at once, deprived themselves of the gain of which they were assured day by day.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 驴和青蛙
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Ass and the Frogs

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一头驴载着很多木头，要趟过一个池塘。趟水时，驴失足绊了一跤，摔倒了。因为身上载着东西，驴站不起来，就大声呻吟。经常呆在这个池塘里的几只青蛙听到了驴的哀叹声，说道：“只是在水里摔了一跤，你就如此小题大做，如果你像我们一样必须一直生活在这里，你该怎么办呢？”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: An Ass, carrying a load of wood, passed through a pond.As he was crossing through the water he lost his footing, stumbled and fell, and not being able to rise on account of his load, groaned heavily.Some Frogs frequenting the pool heard his lamentation, and said, “What would you do if you had to live here always as we do, when you make such a fuss about a mere fall into the water?”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 人们在面对小困难时，往往失去了面对大灾难时的勇气。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Men often bear little grievances with less courage than they do large misfortunes.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 乌鸦和渡鸦
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Crow and the Raven

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只乌鸦嫉妒渡鸦，因为渡鸦被视作是一种吉祥鸟，总能引人注目；人们常通过观察渡鸦的飞行以预测未来事件发展的好坏。这只乌鸦看到几个旅行者走过来，就飞到一棵树上，栖息在枝头，尽可能大声地呱呱叫起来。旅行者们循声望去，想知道这预示着什么。其中一个旅行者对他的同伴说：“我们继续赶路吧，朋友，因为这只是一只乌鸦的叫声。你知道，乌鸦的叫声没有什么征兆可言。”假装拥有不属于自己的特质，只会让自己显得荒唐可笑。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Crow was jealous of the Raven, because he was considered a bird of good omen and always attracted the attention of men, who noted by his flight the good or evil course of future events.Seeing some travelers approaching, the Crow flew up into a tree, and perching herself on one of the branches, cawed as loudly as she could.The travelers turned towards the sound and wondered what it foreboded, when one of them said to his companion, “Let us proceed on our journey, my friend, for it is only the caw of a crow, and her cry, you know, is no omen.”Those who assume a character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 树林和斧子
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Trees and the Axe

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一个人来到森林里，请求树林给他一个木柄做斧柄。树林同意了他的请求，给了他一棵小白蜡树。这个人刚给他的斧子安上了新斧柄，就开始用这把斧子迅速砍倒了森林里最为珍贵的参天大树。一棵老橡树看到它的同伴们被砍伐，悲叹不已，但为时已晚。它对旁边的一棵雪松说：“第一招失误，让我们全盘皆输啊。如果我们没有放弃那棵白蜡树，我们或许还可以保留我们自己的特权，顶住侵袭。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A man came into a forest and asked the Trees to provide him a handle for his axe.The Trees consented to his request and gave him a young ashtree.No sooner had the man fitted a new handle to his axe from it, than he began to use it and quickly felled with his strokes the noblest giants of the forest.An old oak, lamenting when too late the destruction of his companions, said to a neighboring cedar, “The first step has lost us all.If we had not given up the rights of the ash, we might yet have retained our own privileges and have stood forages.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 螃蟹和狐狸
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Crab and the Fox

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只螃蟹离开海岸，选择了临近的一片绿草地作为自己的掠食基地。一只饥肠辘辘的狐狸碰到了这只螃蟹，一口就把它给吞掉了。就在它即将被吞掉的当口，螃蟹说：“我活该有这样的下场。我的本性和习惯都决定了我只适合在海洋里生存，我来陆地上能干什么呢？”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Crab, forsaking the seashore, chose a neighboring green meadow as his feeding ground.A Fox came across him, and being very hungry ate him up.Just as he was on the point of being eaten, the Crab said, “I well deserve my fate, for what business had I on the land, when by my nature and habits I am only adapted for the sea?”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 知足常乐。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 青蛙对太阳的抱怨
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Frogs’ Complaint Against the Sun

狮子、熊和狐狸: 从前，太阳宣称要娶一位妻子。青蛙们听到这个消息，纷纷对着天空大声叫嚷。它们的吵闹声打扰到了朱庇特，朱庇特就询问它们抱怨的原因。其中一只青蛙说：“现在的太阳只是单身，他就烘烤着湿地，迫使我们在干涸的家中痛苦地死去。如果以后他生出其他更多的太阳，那我们的将来会是什么样子？”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Once upon time, when the Sun announced his intention to take a wife, the Frogs lifted up their voices in clamor to the sky.Jupiter, disturbed by the noise of their croaking, inquired the cause of their complaint. One of them said, “The Sun, now while he is single, parches up the marsh, and compels us to die miserably in our arid homes.What will be our future condition if he should beget other suns?”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 好事和坏事
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Goods and the Ills

狮子、熊和狐狸: 从前，所有的好事都被坏事从人类事务中排挤出来，而它们原本是共存的；那些坏事凭借它们数量的优势掌控地球。好事便飘上天堂，要求对迫害它们的坏事进行正义的报复。它们恳求朱庇特说，它们再也不能和坏事有任何干连，因为它们和坏事没有任何共同之处，也无法共存，只能陷入无休止的战争，还说，为了保护它们的未来，应当制定一条牢不可破的法律。朱庇特答应了它们的要求，并且颁布法令说，从此以后，所有的坏事应该结伴访问人间，而好事应该一个个地进入人类的住宅。从此，就出现了这样的情况，坏事结伴来临，它们不是一个一个地出现，而是成群出现，决不单独出现。而从朱庇特那里出来的好事则不同，是单独并且分开赐予的，而且是一个一个给那些能够辨别它们的人。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: ALL the Goods were once driven out by the Ills from that common share which they each had in the affairs of mankind; for the Ills by reason of their numbers had prevailed to possess the earth.The Goods wafted themselves to heaven and asked for a righteous vengeance on their persecutors.They entreated Jupiter that they might no longer be associated with the Ills, as they had nothing in common and could not live together, but were engaged in unceasing warfare; and that an indissoluble law might be laid down for their future protection.Jupiter granted their request and decreed that henceforth the Ills should visit the earth in company with each other, but that the Goods should one by one enter the habitations of men.Hence it arises that Ills abound, for they come not one by one, but in troops, and by no means singly: while the Goods proceed from Jupiter, and are given, not alike to all, but singly, and separately; and one by one to those who are able to discern them.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 妇人和她的母鸡
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Woman and Her Hen

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一个妇人有一只母鸡，这只母鸡每天为她下一个蛋。她常常想怎么才能让母鸡每天下两个蛋，而不是一个。为了达到目的，最终她决定喂母鸡双份的大麦。从那天起，母鸡开始变肥，鸡毛也变得柔滑光亮，但却再也没下过一个蛋。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Woman possessed a Hen that gave her an egg every day.She often pondered how she might obtain two eggs daily instead of one, and at last, to gain her purpose, determined to give the Hen a double allowance of barley.From that day the Hen became fat and sleek, and never once laid another egg.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 驴和老牧羊人
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Ass and the Old Shepherd

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一个牧羊人正在看着草地上的驴吃草，突然听到敌人的呐喊声，惊慌不已。他让驴和他一起逃跑，免得都被抓住。但是驴却懒洋洋地回答道：“请问，我为什么要跑呢？你觉得征服者有可能会在我身上放两副驮篮吗？”“不会。”牧羊人回答说。“那么，”驴说，“既然都要载着驮篮，我为谁劳动又有什么关系呢？”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Shepherd watching his Ass feeding in a meadow, was alarmed all of a sudden by the cries of the enemy.He appealed to the Ass to fly with him, lest they should both be captured, but the animal lazily replied, “Why should I, pray?Do you think it likely the conqueror will place on me two sets of panniers?”“No,” rejoined the Shepherd.“Then,” said the Ass, “as long as I carry the panniers, what matters it to me whom I serve?”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 政权的更迭并不能为穷人带来任何变化，只是当政者的名字换了而已。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: In a change of government the poor change nothing beyond the name of their master.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 风筝和天鹅
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Kites and the Swans

狮子、熊和狐狸: 古时候，风筝和天鹅一样，拥有唱歌的天赋。但是当它们听到马的嘶鸣声后便陶醉其中，于是它们试图模仿马的嘶鸣声。在模仿的过程中，它们竟忘记怎么唱歌了。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Kites of olden times, as well as the Swans, had the privilege of song.But having heard the neigh of the horse, they were so enchanted with the sound, that they tried to imitate it; and, in trying to neigh, they forgot how to sing.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 觊觎不切实际的利益常常会让自己失去眼前的幸福。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The desire for imaginary benefits often involves the loss of present blessings.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狼和牧羊犬
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Wolves and the Sheepdogs

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狼对牧羊犬这样说道：“咱们这么多方面都相似，你们和我们的看法怎么不一致，不和我们像兄弟一样住在一起呢？我们和你们只有一点不同。我们生活自由，而你们却卑躬屈膝，当人类的奴隶。人类回报你们劳动的却是用皮鞭抽打你们，在你们的脖子上套上项圈。他们还让你们看守羊群。他们吃羊肉，却只把骨头扔给你们。如果你们相信我们，就把这些羊送给我们吧。咱们可以一起享用，直到吃腻为止。”牧羊犬听从了这些提议，于是进了狼窝。结果，狼群猛扑过去，把牧羊犬撕得粉碎。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Wolves thus addressed the Sheepdogs: “Why should you, who are like us in so many things, not be entirely of one mind with us, and live with us as brothers should?We differ from you in one point only.We live in freedom, but you bow down to and slave for men, who in return for your services flog you with whips and put collars on your necks.They make you also guard their sheep, and while they eat the mutton throw only the bones to you.If you will be persuaded by us, you will give us the sheep, and we will enjoy them in common, till we all are surfeited.”The Dogs listened favorably to these proposals, and, entering the den of the Wolves, they were set upon and torn to pieces.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 野兔和狐狸
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Hares and the Foxes

狮子、熊和狐狸: 野兔要和老鹰打仗，于是恳求狐狸援助他们。狐狸回复说：“如果我们不知道你们是谁，不知道你们和谁打仗，我们是很愿意帮助你们的。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Hares waged war with the Eagles, and called upon the Foxes to help them.They replied, “We would willingly have helped you, if we had not known who you were, and with whom you were fighting.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 接受别人的委托之前要先衡量自己的得失。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Count the cost before you commit yourselves.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 弓箭手和狮子
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Bowman and Lion

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一个箭法娴熟的弓箭手去山上打猎，但是森林里所有的野兽看到他来就都逃离了。只有狮子独自向人挑战。弓箭手立即射出一支箭，对狮子说：“我送去我的使者，通过他，你或许能知道等我亲自攻击你时会如何。”受伤的狮子惊恐万分、仓皇逃窜。狐狸看到了这一切，便告诉狮子要大胆些，不要受到一次攻击就后退。狮子回答说：“你劝我也没有用。假如他能派出这么可怕的使者，我又怎么能经受得住他本人的攻击呢？”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A very skillful Bowman went to the mountains in search of game, but all the beasts of the forest fled at his approach.The Lion alone challenged him to combat.The Bowman immediately shot out an arrow and said to the Lion: “I send thee my messenger, that from him thou mayest learn what I myself shall be when I assail thee.”The wounded Lion rushed away in great fear, and when a Fox who had seen it all happen told him to be of good courage and not to back off at the first attack he replied: “You counsel me in vain; for if he sends so fearful a messenger, how shall I abide the attack of the man himself?”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 当心能从远处攻击你的人。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Be on guard against men who can strike from a distance.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 骆驼
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Camel

狮子、熊和狐狸: 人类第一次看到骆驼时，被骆驼硕大的体型吓得转身就跑。一段时间后，人类发现这种动物性情温驯，就鼓足勇气去接近它。不久，人类发现骆驼是一种完全缺乏反抗精神的动物，就大胆地给它套上了缰绳，让小孩赶着它。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: When man first saw the Camel, he was so frightened at his vast size that he ran away.After a time, perceiving the meekness and gentleness of the beast’s temper, he summoned courage enough to approach him.Soon afterwards, observing that he was an animal altogether deficient in spirit, he assumed such boldness as to put a bridle in his mouth, and to let a child drive him.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 习惯有助于克服恐惧。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Use serves to overcome dread.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 黄蜂和蛇
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Wasp and the Snake

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只黄蜂落在蛇的头上，不停地用他的螫针叮蛇，要置蛇于死地。蛇经受着极大的折磨，不知道该如何摆脱他的敌人。这时，蛇看到一辆满载木头的马车，就上前故意把头放在车轮下面，说道：“至少我可以和我的敌人同归于尽。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Wasp seated himself upon the head of a Snake and, striking him unceasingly with his stings, wounded him to death.The Snake, being in great torment and not knowing how to rid himself of his enemy, saw a wagon heavily laden with wood, and went and purposely placed his head under the wheels, saying, “At least my enemy and I shall perish together.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狗和野兔
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Dog and the Hare

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一条猎狗惊动了山坡上的一只野兔，并追赶了她一段距离。猎狗一会儿用牙齿咬兔子，好像要置她于死地；一会儿又奉承讨好兔子，好像在和一条狗嬉戏玩耍。野兔对猎狗说：“我希望你能对我真诚一些，现出你的真实面目吧。如果你是朋友，为什么咬我这么狠？如果你是敌人，为什么又来奉承讨好我？”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A hound having started a Hare on the hillside pursued her for some distance, at one time biting her with his teeth as if he would take her life, and at another fawning upon her, as if in play with another dog.The Hare said to him, “I wish you would act sincerely by me, and show yourself in your true colors.If you are a friend, why do you bite me so hard?If an enemy, why do you fawn on me?”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 当你不知道该信任还是怀疑他人时，就不能把他当作朋友。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust him.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 公牛和小牛
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Bull and the Calf

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一头公牛正竭尽全力挤过一条通往自己牛栏的狭窄通道。一头小牛走过来，表示愿意走在前面给公牛带路，这条路是公牛能够通过的。“不用麻烦你了，”公牛说，“早在你出生之前，我就知道那条路了。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Bull was striving with all his might to squeeze himself through a narrow passage which led to his stall.A young Calf came up, and offered to go before and show him the way by which he could manage to pass.“Save yourself the trouble,” said the Bull; “I knew that way long before you were born.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 牡鹿、狼和羊
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Stag, the Wolf, and the Sheep

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只牡鹿让一只羊借给他一定量的小麦，并让狼当他的担保人。羊担心其中有诈，为了拒绝牡鹿的要求就自我辩解道：“狼习惯于想猎取什么就夺取什么，然后就跑掉；而你也跑得那么神速，很快就能超过我。如果还小麦的时间到了，我怎么才能找到你们呢？”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Stag asked a Sheep to lend him a measure of wheat, and said that the Wolf would be his surety.The Sheep, fearing some fraud was intended, excused herself, saying, “The Wolf is accustomed to seize what he wants and to run off; and you, too, can quickly outstrip me in your rapid flight.How then shall I be able to find you, when the day of payment comes?”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 两黑不等于一白。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Two blacks do not make one white.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 孔雀和仙鹤
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Peacock and the Crane

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只孔雀正在开屏，绚丽多彩。一只仙鹤从旁边经过，孔雀便嘲笑仙鹤苍白的羽毛，挖苦道：“我穿着金色、紫色和彩虹般五彩缤纷的长袍，像国王一样华丽尊贵，而你的翅膀却没有一点色彩。”“确实是这样，”鹤回答说，“但是我能在高空翱翔，能对着星星引吭高歌，而你却只能像只公鸡一样，与地面粪堆上的鸟群为伍。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Peacock spreading its gorgeous tail mocked a Crane that passed by, ridiculing the ashen hue of its plumage and saying, “I am robed, like a king, in gold and purple and all the colors of the rainbow; while you have not a bit of color on your wings.”“True,” replied the Crane; “but I soar to the heights of heaven and lift up my voice to the stars, while you walk below, like a cock, among the birds of the dunghill.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 仅凭漂亮的羽毛并不能成为高贵的鸟。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Fine feathers don’t make fine birds.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狐狸和刺猬
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Fox and the Hedgehog

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只狐狸正要游过一条急流，却被水流冲到了一个很深的峡谷里。他被碰得全身淤青，病怏怏地躺在那里，很长时间都不能动弹。一群饥饿的吸血蝇停落在了他的身上。这时，一只刺猬路过，看到狐狸很痛苦，就问狐狸要不要赶走正在折磨他的吸血蝇。“千万不要，”狐狸回答说，“请不要打扰他们。”“怎么了？”刺猬说，“难道你不想摆脱他们吗？”“不，”狐狸回答说，“因为你看到的这些吸血蝇已经吸饱了，他们现在几乎没在叮我了。如果你帮我赶走这些已经吸饱了的吸血蝇，其他更饿的就会过来代替他们，接着吸光我所有剩下的血。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Fox swimming across a rapid river was carried by the force of the current into a very deep ravine, where he lay for a long time very much bruised, sick, and unable to move.A swarm of hungry blood-sucking flies settled upon him.A Hedgehog, passing by, saw his anguish and inquired if he should drive away the flies that were tormenting him.“By no means,” replied the Fox; “pray do not molest them.”“How is this?” said the Hedgehog; “do you not want to be rid of them?’ “No,” returned the Fox, “for these flies which you see are full of blood, and sting me but little, and if you rid me of these which are already satiated, others more hungry will come in their place, and will drink up all the blood I have left.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 鹰、猫和野母猪
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Eagle, the Cat, and the Wild Sow

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只鹰在一棵高大的橡树顶部筑了一个巢；一只猫发现树干中部有个现成的洞穴，就搬了进去；一头野母猪和她的幼崽则躲在大树根部的一个洞里。狡猾的猫决定破坏这个偶然形成的聚居群。为了实施她的计谋，她爬到鹰巢里，说：“灾难就要降临到你和我的身上了，真是不幸。你看那只野母猪每天都在掘土，她是要连根推倒橡树啊。这样，树一倒下，她就可以抓住我们的家人给她的幼崽当食物了。”猫把鹰吓得惊慌失措后，又爬到母猪的洞穴里说：“你的孩子们很危险呀。因为只要你带着你的孩子们出去觅食，那只鹰就会准备冲下来叼走你的其中一只小猪。”猫让母猪也深感恐慌之后离开了，还装模作样地躲进了树洞里。到了晚上，她就蹑手蹑脚地去给自己和她的小猫觅食，而白天就假装很害怕的样子，整天都小心提防着。此时，鹰对母猪满怀恐惧，静静地立在树枝上；而母猪也惧怕鹰，不敢从洞穴中出来。就这样，鹰和母猪以及她们的孩子都被饿死了，从而为猫和她的孩子们提供了充足的食物。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: An Eagle made her nest at the top of a lofty oak; a Cat, having found a convenient hole, moved into the middle of the trunk; and a Wild Sow, with her young, took shelter in a hollow at its foot.The Cat cunningly resolved to destroy this chance-made colony.To carry out her design, she climbed to the nest of the Eagle, and said, “Destruction is preparing for you, and for me too, unfortunately.The Wild Sow, whom you see daily digging up the earth, wishes to uproot the oak, so she may on its fall seize our families as food for her young.”Having thus frightened the Eagle out of her senses, she crept down to the cave of the Sow, and said, “Your children are in great danger; for as soon as you go out with your litter to find food, the Eagle is prepared to pounce upon one of your little pigs.”Having instilled these fears into the Sow, she went and pretended to hide herself in the hollow of the tree.When night came she went forth with silent foot and obtained food for herself and her kittens, but feigning to be afraid, she kept a lookout all through the day. Meanwhile, the Eagle, full of fear of the Sow, sat still on the branches, and the Sow, terrified by the Eagle, did not dare to go out from her cave.And thus they both, along with their families, perished from hunger, and afforded ample provision for the Cat and her kittens.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 小偷和旅店老板
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Thief and the Innkeeper

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一个小偷在一家旅店租了一间房。他在那里住了一段时间，希望能够偷些东西，好让他付清账单。可等了几天，他仍一无所获。这时，他看见旅店老板穿了一件漂亮的新外套坐在他的门前。于是，小偷坐到老板旁边，和他闲聊起来。谈话变得索然无味时，小偷打了一个大大的哈欠，同时发出了狼一般的嚎叫声。旅店老板问：“你怎么叫得这么吓人呢？”“我会告诉你的，”小偷说，“但是请你先抓住我的衣服，要不然我会把衣服撕得粉碎。先生，我不知道从什么时候开始养成了这样打哈欠的习惯，也不知道嚎叫发作是对我所犯罪行的惩罚，还是有其他什么原因。我只知道，等我第三次打哈欠的时候，我竟然会变成一匹狼，去攻击人类。”说着他就开始打第二个哈欠，又发出了狼一般的嚎叫声，跟第一次一样。旅店老板听完小偷的故事，信以为真，便大惊失色，起身打算逃跑。小偷抓住他的外套，恳求他留下来，说道：“请等等，先生，请抓住我的衣服，否则等我变成狼时，我会一气之下把它们撕得粉碎。”与此同时，他打了第三个哈欠，发出了恐怖的嚎叫声。旅店老板吓坏了，唯恐自己受到攻击，便把自己的新外套留在小偷手里，飞快地跑进旅店躲避去了。小偷带着这件外套溜掉了，再也没有回过旅店。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Thief hired a room in a tavern and stayed a while in the hope of stealing something which should enable him to pay his reckoning.When he had waited some days in vain, he saw the Innkeeper dressed in a new and handsome coat and sitting before his door.The Thief sat down beside him and talked with him.As the conversation began to flag, the Thief yawned terribly and at the same time howled like a wolf.The Innkeeper said, “Why do you howl so fearfully?’ “I will tell you,” said the Thief, “but first let me ask you to hold my clothes, or I shall tear them to pieces.I know not, sir, when I got this habit of yawning, nor whether these attacks of howling were inflicted on me as a judgment for my crimes, or for any other cause; but this I do know, that when I yawn for the third time, I actually turn into a wolf and attack men.”With this speech he commenced a second fit of yawning and again howled like a wolf, as he had at first.The Innkeeper, hearing his tale and believing what he said, became greatly alarmed and, rising from his seat, attempted to run away. The Thief laid hold of his coat and entreated him to stop, saying, “Pray wait, sir, and hold my clothes, or I shall tear them to pieces in my fury, when I turn into a wolf.”At the same moment he yawned the third time and set up a terrible howl.The Innkeeper, frightened lest he should be attacked, left his new coat in the Thief’s hand and ran as fast as he could into the inn for safety.The Thief made off with the coat and did not return again to the inn.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 并非每个故事都是可信的。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Every tale is not to be believed.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 骡子
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Mule

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一头骡子因没有多少活干，谷物又特别多，感觉很是快活，便放肆地四处飞奔。他自言自语道：“我的父亲一定是一匹很勇猛的赛马，而我肯定继承了他的速度和勇气。”第二天，他被赶着走了一段很长的路，疲惫不堪。他闷闷不乐地大声说道：“我一定是弄错了，可能我的父亲终究只是一头驴吧。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Mule, frolicsome from lack of work and from too much corn, galloped about in a very extravagant manner, and said to himself: “My father surely was a high-mettled racer, and I am his own child in speed and spirit.”On the next day, being driven a long journey, and feeling very wearied, he exclaimed in a disconsolate tone: “I must have made a mistake; my father, after all, could have been only an ass.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 公鹿和藤蔓
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Hart and the Vine

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只公鹿被穷追不舍，便藏到一条藤蔓的大叶子下面。匆忙中，猎人们越过了公鹿的藏身之处。公鹿以为所有的危险都已过去，便开始慢慢啃噬藤蔓。其中一个猎人听到叶子沙沙作响，便回头看，发现了这只公鹿。于是他拉开弓，一箭射中了它。 公鹿临死时叹息道：“我活该如此，我不该伤害救了我的藤蔓啊。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Hart hard pressed in the chase, hid himself beneath the large leaves of a Vine.The huntsmen, in their haste, overshot the place of his concealment.Supposing all danger to have passed, the Hart began to nibble the tendrils of the Vine.One of the huntsmen, attracted by the rustling of the leaves, looked back, and seeing the Hart, shot an arrow from his bow and struck it.The Hart, at the point of death, groaned: “I am rightly served, for I should not have maltreated the Vine that saved me.”

狮子、熊和狐狸: 蛇和鹰
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Serpent and the Eagle

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一条蛇和一只鹰正在进行一场殊死搏斗。蛇占了上风，马上就要把鹰勒死了。一个农夫看到这一情景，便跑过去，解开了盘绕着的蛇，让鹰飞走了。由于猎物跑掉了，蛇很愤怒，便把自己的毒液投到了农夫的角杯里。农夫对危险一无所知。他正要喝酒时，那只鹰用翅膀拍打农夫的手，用爪子抓起角杯，把它带到了高空中。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Serpent and an Eagle were struggling with each other in deadly conflict.The Serpent had the advantage, and was about to strangle the bird.A countryman saw them, and running up, loosed the coil of the Serpent and let the Eagle go free.The Serpent, irritated at the escape of his prey, injected his poison into the drinking horn of the countryman.The rustic, ignorant of his danger, was about to drink, when the Eagle struck his hand with his wing, and, seizing the drinking horn in his talons, carried it aloft.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 乌鸦和水罐
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Crow and the Pitcher

狮子、熊和狐狸: 一只快要渴死的乌鸦看到一个水罐，希望能够找到水喝，就高兴地飞了过去。等他飞过去，却不幸地发现里面的水太浅了，他是不可能够到的。乌鸦尝试用各种他能想到的办法好喝到水，但所有的努力都是白费。最后，他将能搬动的石子都堆积到一起，然后用嘴把石头一块块地叼进水罐中，直到水升到他能够喝到为止。就这样，乌鸦终于得救了。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A Crow perishing with thirst saw a pitcher, and hoping to find water, flew to it with delight.When he reached it, he discovered to his grief that it contained so little water that he could not possibly get at it.He tried everything he could think of to reach the water, but all his efforts were in vain.At last he collected as many stones as he could carry and dropped them one by one with his beak into the pitcher, until he brought the water within his reach and thus saved his life.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 需要是发明之母。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Necessity is the mother of invention.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 两只青蛙
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Two Frogs

狮子、熊和狐狸: 两只青蛙毗邻而居。一只住在深水塘里，远离公众视线；另一只则住在浅水沟里，一条乡间小路穿行其间。住在深水塘里的青蛙劝他的朋友换个住处，并请求他来跟自己一起住。说这样他可以远离危险、更加安全，食物也更为充足。住在浅水沟里的那只青蛙拒绝了，因为他觉得离开自己已经住惯了的地方实在太难了。几天后，一辆大马车经过水沟，把他碾死在了车轮之下。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: Two Frogs were neighbors.One inhabited a deep pond, far removed from public view; the other lived in a gully containing little water, and traversed by a country road.The Frog that lived in the pond warned his friend to change his residence and entreated him to come and live with him, saying that he would enjoy greater safety from danger and more abundant food.The other refused, saying that he felt it so very hard to leave a place to which he had become accustomed.A few days afterwards a heavy wagon passed through the gully and crushed him to death under its wheels.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 固执的人将为自己的固执付出代价。
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: A willful man will have his way to his own hurt.

狮子、熊和狐狸: 狼和狐狸
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: The Wolf and the Fox

狮子、熊和狐狸: 从前，狼群中诞生了一匹身形高大、体格强壮的狼。他的力量、体格、速度都超过了他的同类，因此其他狼一致决定叫他“狮子”。这匹狼对自己超大号的身形比例缺乏认识，以为其他狼是很认真地给他取了这个称号。于是，他离开自己的种群，只和狮子们来往。一只狡猾的老狐狸见此，说道：“但愿我永远也不要像你那样骄傲、自大得可笑。虽然你在狼群中有狮子一般的身形，但在狮群中，你无疑还是一匹狼啊。”
The Lion, the Bear, and the Fox: One time a very large and strong Wolf was born among the wolves, who exceeded all his fellow-wolves in strength, size, and swiftness, so that they unanimously decided to call him “Lion.”The Wolf, with a lack of sense proportioned to his enormous size, thought that they gave him this name in earnest, and, leaving his own race, consorted exclusively with the lions.An old sly Fox, seeing this, said, “May I never make myself so ridiculous as you do in your pride and self-conceit; for even though you have the size of a lion among wolves, in a herd of lions you are definitely a wolf.”
